title: How to Cook Binagoongang Baboy

steps.headline: Fry the sliced eggplant in oil for 3 minutes on each side.
steps.description: Heat 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of your desired cooking oil in a saucepan. Add 1 sliced Chinese eggplant and fry it for 3 minutes. Flip the slices over with a spatula or a pair of tongs, then cook them for another 3 minutes. Use an actual saucepan and not a frying pan. If you use a frying pan, you won't have enough room in it to cook the rest of the meal.

steps.headline: Transfer the fried eggplant to a plate with a spatula or a pair of tongs.
steps.description: Set the plate aside while you prepare the rest of the meal. For a less-greasy meal, place a paper towel on the plate first so that the eggplant slices can drain. Do not drain the oil from the pot. You need this extra oil to sauté the rest of the ingredients.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion, tomato, and garlic in the pot with oil for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) oil to the pot you just took the eggplant out of. Let it get hot again, then add 1 large, diced yellow onion 2 diced medium-sized plum tomatoes, and 1 teaspoon (2.8 g) of minced garlic. Fry and stir the ingredients with a wooden spatula for about 5 minutes, or until the onion turns golden brown. If the pot starts to get too dry and the ingredients burn, add a little more cooking oil. About 1 tablespoon (15 mL) will do.

steps.headline: Add the pork and cook it for a few minutes, or until it turns light brown.
steps.description: Cut 1 ⁄2 pounds (0.68 kg) of pork shoulder into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes. Toss it into the pot and let it cook until it turns light brown. Stir it often so that it browns evenly on all sides. You're not cooking the pork all the way through here. You're just browning it to lock the juices in. If you don't have pork shoulder, try 1 ⁄2 pounds (0.68 kg) of pork belly instead.

steps.headline: Pour in the beef broth and simmer it for 45 to 60 minutes, covered.
steps.description: Pour 2 ⁄2 cups (590 mL) of beef broth into the pot. Bring the broth to a boil over medium to high heat, then immediately reduce it to a simmer. Cover the pot with a lid and let it cook for 45 to 60 minutes. The broth is ready when the pork is tender.

steps.headline: Stir in the shrimp paste, then cook it for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Add 1/4 cup (55 g) of shrimp paste into the pot. Stir it in, then let it cook for 3 to 5 minutes over low to medium heat. The pot should still have liquid in it. If it evaporated, stir in 1 cup (240 mL) of beef broth.

steps.headline: Season the stew with salt and pepper, then serve with the fried eggplant.
steps.description: For a more filling meal, add some steamed rice as well. You can serve everything on a single platter, or you can serve the eggplant, stew, and rice in separate dishes. Refrigerate any leftovers in an airtight container for up to 4 days.

steps.headline: Boil the pork belly in a small pot for 15 to 20 minutes, then set it aside.
steps.description: Cut 1.1 pounds (0.50 kg) of pork belly into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes. Place it into a small pot, then cover it with water. Cover the pot with a lid and allow it to cook over medium-high to high heat for 15 to 20 minutes. If you can't get pork belly, use 1.1 pounds (0.50 kg) of pork shoulder instead. Take the pot off the stove and set it aside once the pork is cooked. Do not drain the water from the pot. You need this for the broth. How much water you use will vary. Just use enough to cover the pork.

steps.headline: Sauté the garlic in the oil until it becomes fragrant.
steps.description: Pour 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of cooking oil into a medium-sized carajay or wok, then turn the heat up to medium-high or high. Wait for the oil to start bubbling, then add the 3 chopped garlic cloves. Fry the garlic until it becomes fragrant. This may take 2 to 3 minutes. Stir the garlic often with a wooden spatula as it cooks. This will keep it from sticking to the pan. If you don't have a carajay or wok, use a deep frying pan or skillet. You can also try a regular saucepan.

steps.headline: Toss in the onion and continue to cook it for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Peel and chop a small red onion, then add it into the wok. Cook it for 2 to 3 minutes, or until it turns soft. Be sure to stir the mixture often with your spatula so that it cooks evenly.

steps.headline: Stir the tomatoes into the onions and cook them until they turn soft.
steps.description: Chop 3 small tomatoes and scoop them into the onion mixture. Sauté them for 2 to 3 minutes, or until they turn soft and mushy. The texture should be similar to that of chunky pasta sauce.

steps.headline: Add the shrimp paste and pork, then sauté it for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Stir in 1/4 cup (55 g) of shrimp paste, and fry it for 2 to 3 minutes, stirring the mixture often with a wooden spatula. Next, add in the boiled pork, and fry it until it turns golden brown, about 1 minute. For a less-intense shrimp flavor, reduce the paste to 2 tablespoons (30 g).

steps.headline: Pour in ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of pork broth and simmer it for 40 minutes.
steps.description: Measure out ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of the broth from the pot that you cooked the pork in. Add it to the pan, then bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to a simmer, then allow it to cook until the pork is tender; about 30 to 40 more minutes.

steps.headline: Season the dish with vinegar, sugar, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Start with 1½ tablespoons (22.5 mL) of vinegar, 1 teaspoon (4.2 g) of sugar, a dash of salt, and a pinch of pepper. Give the mixture a stir, then taste it. Add more salt or pepper, if desired. If the stew is too thick, add some more pork broth. How much more broth you add is entirely up to you, but be sure to stir it in well. Keep in mind that you'll be adding coconut milk, which will thin it out some more.

steps.headline: Add the eggplant and coconut milk, then simmer it for 8 more minutes.
steps.description: Cut a medium-sized Chinese eggplant into diagonal slices, then add them into the pan. Next, stir in 1 cup (240 mL) of coconut milk. Allow the stew to simmer until it's thick and the eggplants are soft. Depending on the thickness of the eggplants, this will take about 8 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the stew while it is still hot.
steps.description: It tastes delicious enough on its own, but you can also serve it alongside some white rice. If you have any leftovers, put them into a covered container, then store them in the fridge for 3 to 4 days.

text: Making Basic Binagoongang Baboy Fry the sliced eggplant in oil for 3 minutes on each side. Heat 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of your desired cooking oil in a saucepan. Add 1 sliced Chinese eggplant and fry it for 3 minutes. Flip the slices over with a spatula or a pair of tongs, then cook them for another 3 minutes. Use an actual saucepan and not a frying pan. If you use a frying pan, you won't have enough room in it to cook the rest of the meal. Transfer the fried eggplant to a plate with a spatula or a pair of tongs. Set the plate aside while you prepare the rest of the meal. For a less-greasy meal, place a paper towel on the plate first so that the eggplant slices can drain. Do not drain the oil from the pot. You need this extra oil to sauté the rest of the ingredients. Sauté the onion, tomato, and garlic in the pot with oil for 5 minutes. Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) oil to the pot you just took the eggplant out of. Let it get hot again, then add 1 large, diced yellow onion 2 diced medium-sized plum tomatoes, and 1 teaspoon (2.8 g) of minced garlic. Fry and stir the ingredients with a wooden spatula for about 5 minutes, or until the onion turns golden brown. If the pot starts to get too dry and the ingredients burn, add a little more cooking oil. About 1 tablespoon (15 mL) will do. Add the pork and cook it for a few minutes, or until it turns light brown. Cut 1 ⁄2 pounds (0.68 kg) of pork shoulder into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes. Toss it into the pot and let it cook until it turns light brown. Stir it often so that it browns evenly on all sides. You're not cooking the pork all the way through here. You're just browning it to lock the juices in. If you don't have pork shoulder, try 1 ⁄2 pounds (0.68 kg) of pork belly instead. Pour in the beef broth and simmer it for 45 to 60 minutes, covered. Pour 2 ⁄2 cups (590 mL) of beef broth into the pot. Bring the broth to a boil over medium to high heat, then immediately reduce it to a simmer. Cover the pot with a lid and let it cook for 45 to 60 minutes. The broth is ready when the pork is tender. Stir in the shrimp paste, then cook it for 3 to 5 minutes. Add 1/4 cup (55 g) of shrimp paste into the pot. Stir it in, then let it cook for 3 to 5 minutes over low to medium heat. The pot should still have liquid in it. If it evaporated, stir in 1 cup (240 mL) of beef broth. Season the stew with salt and pepper, then serve with the fried eggplant. For a more filling meal, add some steamed rice as well. You can serve everything on a single platter, or you can serve the eggplant, stew, and rice in separate dishes. Refrigerate any leftovers in an airtight container for up to 4 days. Cooking Coconut Binagoongang Baboy Boil the pork belly in a small pot for 15 to 20 minutes, then set it aside. Cut 1.1 pounds (0.50 kg) of pork belly into 1 in (2.5 cm) cubes. Place it into a small pot, then cover it with water. Cover the pot with a lid and allow it to cook over medium-high to high heat for 15 to 20 minutes. If you can't get pork belly, use 1.1 pounds (0.50 kg) of pork shoulder instead. Take the pot off the stove and set it aside once the pork is cooked. Do not drain the water from the pot. You need this for the broth. How much water you use will vary. Just use enough to cover the pork. Sauté the garlic in the oil until it becomes fragrant. Pour 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of cooking oil into a medium-sized carajay or wok, then turn the heat up to medium-high or high. Wait for the oil to start bubbling, then add the 3 chopped garlic cloves. Fry the garlic until it becomes fragrant. This may take 2 to 3 minutes. Stir the garlic often with a wooden spatula as it cooks. This will keep it from sticking to the pan. If you don't have a carajay or wok, use a deep frying pan or skillet. You can also try a regular saucepan. Toss in the onion and continue to cook it for 2 to 3 minutes. Peel and chop a small red onion, then add it into the wok. Cook it for 2 to 3 minutes, or until it turns soft. Be sure to stir the mixture often with your spatula so that it cooks evenly. Stir the tomatoes into the onions and cook them until they turn soft. Chop 3 small tomatoes and scoop them into the onion mixture. Sauté them for 2 to 3 minutes, or until they turn soft and mushy. The texture should be similar to that of chunky pasta sauce. Add the shrimp paste and pork, then sauté it for 2 to 3 minutes. Stir in 1/4 cup (55 g) of shrimp paste, and fry it for 2 to 3 minutes, stirring the mixture often with a wooden spatula. Next, add in the boiled pork, and fry it until it turns golden brown, about 1 minute. For a less-intense shrimp flavor, reduce the paste to 2 tablespoons (30 g). Pour in ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of pork broth and simmer it for 40 minutes. Measure out ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of the broth from the pot that you cooked the pork in. Add it to the pan, then bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to a simmer, then allow it to cook until the pork is tender; about 30 to 40 more minutes. Season the dish with vinegar, sugar, salt, and pepper. Start with 1½ tablespoons (22.5 mL) of vinegar, 1 teaspoon (4.2 g) of sugar, a dash of salt, and a pinch of pepper. Give the mixture a stir, then taste it. Add more salt or pepper, if desired. If the stew is too thick, add some more pork broth. How much more broth you add is entirely up to you, but be sure to stir it in well. Keep in mind that you'll be adding coconut milk, which will thin it out some more. Add the eggplant and coconut milk, then simmer it for 8 more minutes. Cut a medium-sized Chinese eggplant into diagonal slices, then add them into the pan. Next, stir in 1 cup (240 mL) of coconut milk. Allow the stew to simmer until it's thick and the eggplants are soft. Depending on the thickness of the eggplants, this will take about 8 minutes. Serve the stew while it is still hot. It tastes delicious enough on its own, but you can also serve it alongside some white rice. If you have any leftovers, put them into a covered container, then store them in the fridge for 3 to 4 days.
